text: movies are time capsules they tell us
what was in style at the time they were
made what cinematic trends were
happening what the people and places
featured in them looked like and what
the director was thinking and feeling
this was all on my mind recently when I
revisited the 2005 film chef lock and
WAAFs in the movie written and directed
by Patrick Williams it's a micro budget
32 minutes short featuring a cast of
young non-professional actors an action
comedy that tells the story of two best
friends slash crime fighter's in a small
town on the hunt for their arch-nemesis
the title makes it sound like a parody
of Sherlock Holmes but it in explicably
bears no resemblance beyond the names
the film was made in the early days of
digital video before it had become
common in Hollywood productions it shot
on a low resolution mini DV camcorder
creating an aesthetic similar to Steven
Soderbergh full frontal or David Lynch's
Inland Empire except worse but where
those were deliberate artistic choices
here it appears to be made out of
necessity they simply couldn't afford
anything better
Willems also the cinematographer tries
to add some visual texture by
deliberately shooting most of the
exterior scenes with the white balance
set to 3200 Kelvin the color temperature
for tungsten lights
this gives the scenes a distinct cold
blue sheen but it doesn't seem to serve
any function if anything the blue tint
is at odds with the upbeat tone of the
film the only apparent reason for the
choice is that it looked cool when
spielberg did it in Minority Report this
sort of reference without meaning is
indicative of many of the film's choices
it's clearly the product of a 16 year
old boy in the mid-2000s who watched a
lot of Kevin Smith and Quentin Tarantino
and thought the right way to make a
movie was to smear your influences all
over every frame like a toddler
finger-painting and so we have a perfect
time capsule a look back at exactly what
someone like Patrick Williams was into
in 2005 the film begins with a dance
sequence set to the Romanian pop song
dragostea din TEI
better known as the song from the viral
Numa Numa video then there's music from
Final Fantasy 7
Gundam Wing Metal Gear Solid 2

a song from Franz Ferdinand's 2004 debut
album and fight choreography directly
lifted from Crouching Tiger Hidden
Dragon in fact the very first image that
appears on screen text describing the
titular characters as hetero life mates
is a term borrowed from Kevin Smith's
drayan Silent Bob movies I'm Jay this is
my hetero life mates solemn vow
while the onslaught of pop-culture
references is juvenile and somewhat
obnoxious this movie is the right
vehicle for it the film never takes
itself seriously existing in a
fantastical cartoon world in which
supervillains casually shop at toy
stores and the main characters never
take off their jackets or sunglasses
even when indoors in a self-aware moment
the heroes deliberately strike a cool
pose at the end of a fight because
that's what heroes in action movies do
and one chase scene is full of airplane
style gags like the one where chef Locke
is riding a new vehicle every time the
scene cuts back to him unfortunately
this all occurs in a story with
absolutely no stakes of any kind the
inciting incident occurs when the heroes
simply stumble upon one of the villains
henchmen and when they do finally find
the villain who has the absurd
alliterative name of insidious Ichabod
he's just shopping for toys not even
committing a crime watching it you get
the sense that many of these elements
could work in a story that actually had
some semblance of narrative momentum in
which every other scene wasn't simply
the heroes returning home to talk about
what they should do next or where
montages with no story function weren't
dragged out for the full duration of the
songs playing over them like why do we
need a two-minute montage of chef's
flocking WAAFs in driving from one
location to another
because what's admirable about the film
is the way it creates a world with
pre-existing history and relationships
between the characters
when Chef Locke tackles Reginald from a
moving car and interrogate him and his
plush penguin named tubs we understand
this is not the first time it's happened
when a frustrated Waffen reminds chef
Locke that in the US the date is written
differently than in the UK we understand
this is a recurring issue between them
the filmmaking crafts are black there of
let's the film down most during dialogue
scenes I lines are almost never
consistent and one gets the sense that
Willems was entirely unaware of the 180
degree rule may be the strongest visual
a gag in the movie in which Chef Locke
appears to be hit in the face with a
throwing knife only to reveal that he
caught it in his teeth is rendered less
effective by the direction the knife is
thrown in one shot it's moving right to
left and the next left to right if we
simply mirror the initial shot keeping
the knife moving from left to right it
becomes much more effective
while Willam struggles to create a story
worth caring about for the first
two-thirds once the film shifts into its
action-heavy final act the filmmaking
become significantly more confident and
dynamic it's an escalating series of
action scenes a chase scene turns into a
group brawl with a bunch of ninjas which
concludes with a climactic sword fight
it could all benefit from tighter
editing but the geography is clear and
the trace successfully cross cuts
between three planes of parallel action
the final sword fight plays out like a
comedic version of the Michelle Yeoh
zongzi fight from Crouching Tiger Hidden
Dragon but with the added excitement of
watching untrained teenagers dangerously
swing real metal swords at each other
also the subtle sight gag of having
Waffen eating waffles is pretty good but
putting aside the craft what is chef
lock and WAAFs in the movie actually
trying to say well probably not much of
anything
it's intense seems to be just to have
fun with a meaningless celebration of
the media that inspired it but that
doesn't mean it's not about something
this is a movie about two men of unclear
ages who appear to have an inseparable
friendship the women they encounter are
significantly more mature and
professional and chef Locke and often
react with immature hostility when they
correct them or give them advice they
want to keep doing things their own way
and most tellingly of all the villain of
the film is obsessed with toys
constantly distracted from important
matters by children's playthings chef's
lock and WAAFs in the movie is the work
of a filmmaker just over a year away
from graduating high school in the midst
of thinking about college applications
and how he'll soon be leaving his
childhood home and Friends it's a film
about a fear of growing up of having to
put aside childhood interests and
friendships and face real
responsibilities the opening scene shows
the heroes trying and failing at the
simple adult task of making a doctor's
appointment later they put aside their
swords and nunchucks to go inside a
Walmart
only for the scene to end with them
being thrown out and running back home
the film ends with narration from the
directors own mother describing the
success the characters would go on to
have and it feels like a description of
his own hopes and dreams their exploits
was this intentional probably not but
you know death of the author and all
that we are just working with what the
text presents a montage in the middle of
the film is set to the turtles 1967 hit
happy together
when considering the subtext there's
something wistful about it it's a film
made by the director and his friends
about two friends and we can sense this
is one of the last times they would be
happy together
